docs.title: Coding Muscle with R Geospatial
docs.text: Welcome to Coding Muscle with R Geospatial. This comprehensive learning resource is designed to bridge the gap between traditional GIS workflows and modern, programmatic geospatial analysis using the R programming language.

docs.title: Foundation: Data Science Stack
docs.text:
Before diving into maps, we master the core tools that power modern data science in R.

  • Base R ("The Foundation")

    R is built for statistics. Its vectors and matrices are native, making mathematical operations intuitive and fast.

    # Create a vector and calculate mean
data <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
mean(data)

  • Tidyverse ("The Data Engine")

    A collection of R packages designed for data science. Packages like dplyr and tidyr let you filter, sort, and analyze tabular data with a readable syntax.

    library(dplyr)
# Read and filter data
df <- read.csv("data.csv") %>%
  filter(value > 10) %>%
  head()

  • ggplot2 ("The Grammar of Graphics")

    A powerful system for creating elegant data visualizations based on the Grammar of Graphics.

    library(ggplot2)
ggplot(mtcars, aes(x=wt, y=mpg)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  geom_smooth()

docs.title: Applied Geospatial Modules
docs.text:
Once the foundation is set, we apply these skills to specialized geospatial domains using our grid of advanced modules.

Vector Analysis

sf (Simple Features)

Master the manipulation of geometric data using tidy principles.

library(sf)
nc <- st_read(system.file("shape/nc.shp", package="sf"))
plot(st_geometry(nc))
Raster Processing

terra & stars

Unlock the power of pixel-based data (Satellite imagery, DEMs).

library(terra)
r <- rast("image.tif")
plot(r)
Time Series

tsibble & lubridate

Handle temporal data with precision for meteorological trends.

library(lubridate)
df$date <- ymd(df$date_string)
# Monthly aggregate
df %>% group_by(month = month(date)) %>% summarize(mean(val))
Web APIs & Cloud

httr & jsonlite

Connect to live APIs like OpenWeatherMap.

library(httr)
res <- GET(api_url)
data <- content(res, "parsed")

docs.title: Characters (Strings)
docs.text:
In R, strings are called "characters".

x <- '2'

class(x)

[1] "character"

y <- "Hello World"

class(y)

[1] "character"

docs.title: String Length
docs.text:
Unlike Python's len(), R uses nchar() for the number of characters in a string.

nchar("Hello World")

[1] 11

docs.title: String Indexing
docs.text:
R is 1-indexed. To get a substring, use substr().

# Get the first character
substr(y, 1, 1)

[1] "H"

# Get characters from 7 to 11
substr(y, 7, 11)

[1] "World"

docs.title: String Concatenation
docs.text:
R uses paste() or paste0() for concatenation.

first_name <- 'Madhya'
last_name <- 'Pradesh'
full_name <- paste(first_name, last_name)
full_name

[1] "Madhya Pradesh"

docs.title: Numeric and Integer
docs.text:
R handles numbers as numeric (double precision) by default.

a <- 2
class(a)

[1] "numeric"

# Explicit integer
b <- 2L
class(b)

[1] "integer"

docs.title: Type Conversion
docs.text:
x <- "2"
as.numeric(x)

[1] 2

as.character(2.5)

[1] "2.5"

docs.title: Logical (Booleans)
docs.text:
R uses TRUE and FALSE (or T and F).

is_water <- TRUE
class(is_water)

[1] "logical"

docs.title: Character Methods
docs.text:
R has several built-in functions for string manipulation.

toupper("hello")

[1] "HELLO"

tolower("WORLD")

[1] "world"

# Trim whitespace
trimws("   Pune   ")

[1] "Pune"

# Replace
gsub("Jal Shakti", "Jalshakti", "Ministry of Jal Shakti")

[1] "Ministry of Jalshakti"

docs.title: Vectors
docs.text:
Vectors are the most basic data structure in R. They must contain elements of the same type.

# Atomic vector
rain <- c(10, 20, 15, 30)
names(rain) <- c("Mon", "Tue", "Wed", "Thu")
rain

docs.title: Lists
docs.text:
Lists can contain elements of different types, including other lists.

station_info <- list(
  name = "Pune",
  coords = c(18.52, 73.85),
  active = TRUE
)
station_info$name

docs.title: Data Frames
docs.text:
Data frames are the standard for tabular data in R. They are like a list of vectors of equal length.

df <- data.frame(
  station = c("Pune", "Mumbai", "Delhi"),
  rainfall = c(100, 250, 80)
)
summary(df)

docs.title: Matrices
docs.text:
Matrices are two-dimensional arrays where all elements must be of the same type.

m <- matrix(1:9, nrow=3)
m[1, 2] # Row 1, Col 2

docs.title: Factors
docs.text:
Factors are used to represent categorical data.

land_use <- factor(c("Urban", "Forest", "Water", "Urban"))
levels(land_use)

docs.title: Raster Processing with R (terra)
docs.text: The terra package is the successor to the older raster package, providing faster performance for gridded spatial data.

docs.title: Loading and Visualizing Rasters
docs.text:
library(terra)

# Create a sample raster
r <- rast(nrows=10, ncols=10, xmin=0, xmax=10, ymin=0, ymax=10)
values(r) <- 1:100

# Plotting
plot(r, main="Simple Raster")

docs.title: Raster Algebra
docs.text:
# Multi-band operations
r2 <- r * 2
r_sum <- r + r2

# Thresholding
mask <- r > 50
plot(mask)

docs.title: Crop and Mask
docs.text:
# Define an extent
e <- ext(2, 5, 2, 5)

# Crop raster
r_cropped <- crop(r, e)
plot(r_cropped)

docs.title: Tidyverse for Spatial Data
docs.text: The Tidyverse approach makes data cleaning and preparation intuitive, even for spatial attributes.

docs.title: Using dplyr with sf
docs.text:
library(sf)
library(dplyr)

nc <- st_read(system.file("shape/nc.shp", package="sf"))

# Filter counties with more than 10,000 births
large_counties <- nc %>%
  filter(BIR74 > 10000) %>%
  select(NAME, BIR74, geometry)

plot(large_counties["BIR74"])

docs.title: Data Summarization
docs.text:
# Calculate total births by geometry (if grouped)
nc %>%
  summarize(Total_Births = sum(BIR74))

docs.title: Visualization with ggplot2
docs.text:
library(ggplot2)

ggplot(data = nc) +
  geom_sf(aes(fill = BIR74)) +
  scale_fill_viridis_c() +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Birth Statistics", subtitle = "North Carolina 1974")

docs.title: Vector Analysis with R (sf)
docs.text: The sf (Simple Features) package is the modern standard for handling vector data in R. It treats spatial data as a data frame with a list-column for geometry.

docs.title: Loading Data
docs.text:
library(sf)

# Load a built-in shapefile (North Carolina counties)
nc <- st_read(system.file("shape/nc.shp", package="sf"))

# Print first few rows
head(nc)

docs.title: Basic Plotting
docs.text:
# Plot specific attribute
plot(nc["BIR74"], main = "Births in 1974")

# Plot only geometry
plot(st_geometry(nc))

docs.title: Coordinate Reference Systems (CRS)
docs.text:
# Check CRS
st_crs(nc)

# Transform to a different projection (e.g., Web Mercator)
nc_3857 <- st_transform(nc, 3857)

docs.title: Buffering and Intersections
docs.text:
# Create a 10km buffer around the first county
nc_buf <- st_buffer(nc[1, ], dist = 10000)

# Intersection test
overlap <- st_intersects(nc_buf, nc)
